Preparation of nano-PANI@MnO2 by surface initiated polymerization method using as a nano-tubular electrode material: The amount effect of aniline on the microstructure and electrochemical performance Fen Ran a b * Yunlong Yang a Lei Zhao a Xiaoqin Niu b Dingjun Zhang a Lingbin Kong a Yongchun Luo a Long Kang a a State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals, Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou 730050, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals Lanzhou University of Technology Lanzhou Gansu 730050 China b Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, 1156 High Street, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, USA Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry University of California 1156 High Street, Santa Cruz CA 95064 USA * Corresponding author. In this study, nano-polyanline and manganese oxide nanometer tubular composites (nano-PANI@MnO2) were prepared by a surface initiated polymerization method and used as electrochemical capacitor electrode materials; and the effect of aniline amount on the microstructure and electrochemical performance was investigated. The microstructures and surface morphologies of nano-PANI@MnO2 were characterized by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and fourier transformation infrared spectroscope. The electrochemical performance of these composite materials was performed with cyclic voltammetry, charge–discharge test and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, respectively. The results demonstrate that the feed ratio of aniline to MnO2 played a very important role in constructing the hierarchically nano-structure, which would, hence, determine the electrochemical performance of the materials. Using the template-assisted strategy and controlling the feed ratio of aniline to MnO2, the nanometer tubular structure of nano-PANI@MnO2 was obtained. A maximum specific capacitance of 386 F/g was achieved in aqueous 1 mol/L NaNO3 electrolyte with the potential range from 0 to 0.6 V (vs. SCE). Graphical abstract Nano-PANI@MnO2 nanometer tubular composites were prepared by a surface initiated polymerization method and used as electrochemical capacitor electrode materials; and a maximum specific capacitance of 386 F/g was obtained. Keywords Electrochemical capacitors Nano-PANI@MnO2 Electrode materials 1 Introduction The clean energy technology is increasingly being valued under conditions in which the electrical power demand is highly time dependent and growing environmental concerns and increasing depletion of fossil fuels [1–3]. Electrochemical capacitors as a power source are often used in hybrid electric vehicles and mobile electronic devices, which will be used in a wider area in future [4–7]. Currently, most works have been concentrated on electrode materials. The electrochemical capacitors’ performance largely depends on the nature of electrode material, such as component, structure and surface morphology [8]. Conducting polymer and transition-metal oxide as electrode materials have superior capacitive performance. Among various applications of conducting polymers, polyaniline (PANI) has attracted much attention owing to its excellent environmental stability, low cost and its electrical behavior, which can be reversibly controlled by fast charge-transfer doping and by protonation [9–11]. Manganese oxide (MnO2) has the advantages of low cost, natural abundance, environmental friendship and interesting electrochemical performance in the application, which make it look more promising in research [12]. The nanostructured composite materials have great potential in the fields of molecular electronics, electrochemical display devices, catalysis, electro-magnetic shields, microwave-absorbing materials, electrochemical capacitors and batteries [13–15]. There is therefore increasing interest in nanostructured composite material, which is excellent compared to the pure material as they can combine the advantages of both components. At the molecular level, the completely different components of materials not only greatly improve the electrochemical properties, but also provide a synthesis technology of nanocomposite [16–23]. There are several methods to prepare organic-inorganic nanometer composites, for example, electrochemical method [24–27], in-situ method [28,29], etc. Recently, Pan and coworkers synthesized nanometer tubular PANI using crystal-oxidative MnO2 as a template that was dissolved in the reductive environment during synthesis [30]. However, so far, the effects of the feed ratio of aniline to MnO2 on nano-PANI@MnO2’s electrochemical performance and structure by using template-based fabrication technique were rarely reported. In this paper, a template-assisted and surface initiated polymerization method using MnO2 nanorods as an oxidant was designed for synthesis of organic-inorganic nanometer tubular composites of nano-polyanline and manganese oxide (nano-PANI@MnO2); and the effects of aniline amount on the microstructure and electrochemical performance were investigated in detail. The microstructure of nano-PANI@MnO2 was characterized by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and fourier transformation infrared spectroscope, and the supercapacitive behaviors of these composite materials were investigated with cyclic voltammetry, charge-discharge test and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, respectively. The results demonstrated that the nanometer tubular structure was obtained and a maximum specific capacitance of 386 F/g could be achieved in in aqueous 1 mol/L NaNO3 electrolyte with the potential range from 0 to 0.6 V (vs. SCE) 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Aniline (ANI) monomer (analytical grade) and K2CrO7 (analytical grade) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. MnSO4 H2O and NaClO3 were of A.R. grade and received from Shanghai Mei Xing Chemical Reagent Factory, PR China. ANI monomer was distilled until colorless under reduced pressure prior to use. Other chemicals (analytical grade) were used as received without further treatment. 2.2 Synthesis of MnO2 nanorods MnO2 nanorods were synthesized by hydrothermal condition [31]. In the typical process, 0.108 mol of MnSO4 H2O and 0.036 mol of K2Cr2O7 was dissolved into 135 mL deionized water and stirred strongly for several minutes, followed by the addition of 13.5 mL dense sulfuric acid (H2SO4) under continuous stirring. When the solution was completely uniform, the mixture was transferred into a 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave sealed would be put in an oven at 120 °C for reaction about 48 h then it was cooled down to room temperature naturally. In order to remove impurities, the resulting black precipitate was filtered and washed for several times with deionized water, and then dried at 60 °C for 12 h in air. The final products were collected and used for the next experiment. 2.3 The synthesis of nano-PANI@MnO2 composites The process can be described in detail as follows: 1) 0.088 g MnO2 weighed were dispersed in 60 mL deionized water via using ultrasonification and then put in ice bath with slow stirring; 2) the different volume's aniline monomer (0.048 mL, 0.096 mL and 0.144 mL) was added into the mixed solution of 5.6 mL H2SO4 and 34.4 mL deionized water; 3) after the solution mentioned in step 2 was cooled to room temperature, it was added to the mixed solution which was prepared in step 1 under continue stirring quickly. This reaction time was 6 h in ice bath. The green reactive products were purged several times using deionized water and ethanol to remove any ions, which may be remained in the product and monomers. The final products were obtained after drying in vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. 2.4 Structure characterization The characterization of the resulting sample with morphology and microstructure were finished by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-6700 & JSM-6701, Japan). The crystal structure was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD Bruker, D8 Advance, Germany). The functional groups were responded using FT-IR spectrometer (Nexus 670, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (V. G. ESCA Laboratory 210) was used as characterization of composite components and reflecting the composite distribution of micro-structural components. 2.5 Electrochemical tests The mixture containing 80 wt% nano-PANI@MnO2 composite, 7.5 wt% acetylene black, 7.5 wt% graphite, and 5 wt% polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) was well mixed and then pressed onto a Ni-foam current collector (area was 1 cm2) at 1.6 × 107 Pa. The total quantity of the active substance was 8 mg. The electrochemical performances of electrodes were responded with cyclic voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic charge–discharge and impedance spectroscopy test 1 mol/L NaNO3 electrolyte. All tests would be carried out in three electrode systems, which consist of a working electrode, a platinum sheet (the same area as the working electrode) used as counter electrode and a saturated calomel electrode used as reference electrode. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Mechanism of preparation and morphology of material The reactive process between MnO2 and ANI can be described using the equation as shown in Scheme 1 (a). The fabrication process of nano-PANI@MnO2 tubular composites is summarized in Scheme 1(b), which mainly involved the following basic steps: i) preparation of nano-MnO2 template, ii) assembling of ANI molecules on MnO2 surface, iii) surface initiated polymerization of ANI and iv) PANI coating growth. The obtained MnO2 template under hydrothermal condition was spherical bush comprising straight and radially arranged nanorods with smooth surface (Scheme 1c). When the as-prepared MnO2 nanorods were dispersed completely in precooled H2SO4 solution of ANI in ice bath, ANI would be absorbed by MnO2 nanorods. Then MnO2 molecules initiated the polymerization of ANI on the surface of MnO2 template and formed a film with particles covering it (Scheme 1d). As a result, nano-PANI@MnO2 nanotube was obtained due to the surface initiated polymerization of ANI and then the growth of PANI nanoparticles. The obtained nano-PANI@MnO2 nanotubes were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Scheme 1d) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Scheme 1e). The elemental mappings of manganese, carbon, nitrogen and oxygen further reveal that the hybrid structure of nano-PANI@MnO2 composites and demonstrate the obtained product really are the composites of MnO2 and PANI. 3.2 Effect of ANI amount on the material microstructure In order to investigate the morphologies and microstructures of the as-prepared sample on a large scale, the obtained sample was also characterized by SEM. Fig. 1 displays the typical high-and-low magnification SEM images of MnO2 templates and nano-PANI@MnO2 composites. The synthesized MnO2 were spherical bushes comprising straight and radially arranged nanorods with smooth surface (see Fig. 1a and b) [31]. Compared with the microstructure of MnO2, the synthesized nano-PANI@MnO2 composites basically replicated that of the template. It can also be found that with the increase of feed ratio of ANI to MnO2, the morphologies of nano-PANI@MnO2 composites were entirely different. When the amount of ANI is small ([ANI]/[MnO2] = 5/9), limited oxidation reaction happened and there were either eroded or dissolved marks on the surface of MnO2 nanorods. Under this circumstance, the molecular chain length of obtained PANI was short, which maybe lead to much loss of PANI. Because of this, the morphology of the product was incomplete and not smooth (Fig. 1c and d). With the increase of ANI amount ([ANI]/[MnO2] = 10/9), nano-PANI@MnO2 nanometer tubular composites were obtained (Fig. 1e and f). The high magnification SEM images, as shown in Fig. 1(f), present the shape of a single nanotube with a length of 0.8–1 µm and an average width of 190 nm. The SEM images also show that the synthesized nanostructure assembled from nanoparticles. The reason is that MnO2 was reduced into Mn2+, which was used as ANI's oxidant at the same time. Meanwhile, spherical bushes structure of MnO2 was disintegrated. However, the MnO2 nanorods also play an important role as the template in synthesizing nanotube materials. When the amount of ANI was gradually increased to a certain mass ratio ([ANI]/[MnO2] = 20/9) [30], the prepared sample may be completely transformed into PANI (Fig. 1g and h). ANI was added excessively, the oxidatively polymerization of ANI initiated by MnO2 template happened not only on the surface of MnO2 nanorods, but also in the solution by MnO2 pellets which was disintegrated into solution (Fig. 1k and l)). 3.3 Effect of ANI amount on electrochemical performance Fig. 2 shows the dependence of specific capacitance (SC) on the mass ratio of ANI and MnO2. From the figure, it is very clearly to see that SC increased with increasing mass ratio of ANI and MnO2 and the maximum SC locates in the mass ratio of 10/9. This owes to the structure change of composites. When the mass ratio is less than 10/9, the nanostructure of nano-PANI@MnO2 composites haven't formed completely; when the mass ratio is more than 10/9, the increase of the nanorods diameter and the oxidative polymerization of ANI happened in the solution decreased the SC of composite electrodes. In order to further investigate the microstructure and electrochemical performance, the nano-PANI@MnO2 prepared under the mass ratio of 10/9 (named as nano-PANI@MnO2) was selected and studied in detail. 3.4 Characterization of materials FTIR spectra of the prepared MnO2, PANI and nano-PANI@MnO2 composites are shown in Fig. 3 . The peaks located at 3430 and 1628 cm−1 are related to the –OH stretching vibration and bending vibration of MnO2. The band at 532 cm−1 corresponds to the vibration of the Mn–O. The peak around 3430 cm−1 is mainly caused by the –OH stretching vibration of the adsorbed water molecules in the curves of PANI [32]. Characteristic peaks at 1564 and 1478 cm−1 can be observed in the spectrum of PANI. These peaks are attributed to nitrogen quinone (Q) structure and benzenoid structure (B), respectively. The band located at 1298 cm−1 is the C–N stretching vibration of an aromatic amine. The bands at 1115 and 793 cm−1 reflect benzene ring in-plane bending vibration and benzene ring out-of-plane bending vibration, respectively. The band at 503 cm−1 is related to the bending vibration of the aromatic ring. The as-prepared nano-PANI@MnO2 composite has almost the same with the characteristic peaks of PANI [27]. However, the interaction of MnO2 and PANI made the characteristic peaks of PANI slightly shift to low wavenumber in peak position and obviously weaken peak intensities compared with that of PANI. XRD (X-ray powder diffraction) was used to identify the crystalline phase of the as-synthesized MnO2 and nano-PANI@MnO2 composite, as exhibited in Fig. 4 Compared to that of MnO2, the XRD pattern of nano-PANI@MnO2 composite showed a broad peak located in the range of 10°–30° and centered at 2θ = 22°, which is the characteristic peak of amorphous PANI with somewhat of a change in intensity and position compared to the XRD pattern in the literature [33]. It indicates that the composite was thoroughly covered with PANI. The elemental compositions of the resultant nano-PANI@MnO2 composite nanotubes were investigated by X-ray photon-electron spectroscopy. The spectrum in Fig. 5 has slight characteristic peak of Mn element, which further confirm that MnO2 was covered with PANI thoroughly. 3.5 Electrochemical performance analysis To further evaluate the applicability of nano-PANI@MnO2 composite in electrochemical capacitors, cyclic voltammograms (CV) behaviors, the mass specific capacitance and EIS (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy) of composites were investigated in 1 mol/L NaNO3 aqueous solution. The voltammetric responses were employed to evaluate the electrochemical characteristics of the electrode materials. The CV curves of MnO2, PANI and nano-PANI@MnO2 composites are shown in Fig. 6( a). It could be found that all three curves don't exist apparent redox peak in the whole potential range. This implies that the energy storage mechanism of these three electrode materials is mainly electric double-layer storage in electrochemical capacitors. Fig. 6(b) gives the CV behaviors of nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode in three-electrode system and the potential window from −0.2 to 0.8 vs. saturated calomel electrode (SCE) at scanning rates of 5, 10, 15, 20 and 50 mV/s, respectively. At scanning rate of 5 mV/s, the CV curve was closed to the ideal rectangular shape in 1 mol/L NaNO3 electrolyte. It indicates that both high electrochemical reversibility and electric double-layer performance were excellent. This ascribes to the superiority of as-prepared composite. As the scan rate increased, the images of CV gradually became shuttle shape from rectangle due to the fact that ions transport in pores more easily at the low scan rate; however, it can not diffuse into the pores when each fast cycle was completed [34]. The mirror-like charge–discharge curves of MnO2, PANI and nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrodes are almost similar at current density of 5 mA/cm2, as shown in Fig. 7( a). The SC calculated according to the following equation [35] are 6, 276 and 386 F/g. (1) C m = I × Δ t m × Δ V where, C m (F/g) is the specific capacitance, I (A) is discharge current, Δt (s) is the discharging time, ΔV (V) is the potential drop during discharge process, and m (g) is the mass of the active material within the electrode. It was clearly found that synthesized nano-PANI@MnO2 composites have higher capacitance than that of pristine PANI or MnO2 due to the unique hierarchical nanostructure and some synergic function of the two compositions. The charge/discharge curves of nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode at different current densities within a potential window (0–0.6 V vs. SCE) were exhibited as show in Fig. 7(b). The fact that there are no apparent platform in the curves indicates that nano-PANI@MnO2 composite exhibited the ideally capacitive behavior in 1 mol/L NaNO3 solution. By calculating, the SC values of nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode are 386, 317, and 307 F/g corresponding to the current densities of 5, 10 and 20 mA/cm2, respectively. This implies that nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode had good performance of high power. In addition, nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode exhibited better high-power charge-discharge property than that of pristine PANI in 1 mol/L NaNO3 electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 8 . To compare the power properties between nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode and pure PANI electrode in 1 mol/L NaNO3 electrolyte, the retention of the above two materials at 20 mA/cm2 were estimated to around 79.5% and 66.4%, respectively. In order to get more information about the performance of the nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode for electrochemical capacitors application, EIS experiment was carried out at 0.03 V (vs. SCE), as shown in Fig. 9 . The EIS experiment results show distorted semicircle in the high-frequency region and a straight line in the low-frequency region for three curves. There are three features for three curves: firstly, in high-frequency intercept of the real axis, a solution resistance (R s) can be observed, which includes the resistance of the electrolyte, the intrinsic resistance of the active material, and the contact resistance at the interface active material/current collector. The value of MnO2, PANI and nano-PANI@MnO2 composite are approximately 3.8, 1.4 and 1.8 Ω, respectively; secondly, the semicircle diameter of nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode is much smaller than that of pristine PANI, which indicates that the nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode has much lower electrochemical charge-transfer resistance (R ct) [36,37]; finally, in low frequency, the impedance plots exhibit that nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrode the most close to a vertical line than pristine MnO2 and PANI, indicating the composites has more diffusion of ions into the porous structure of the composite-electrolyte interface. These results further proved that synergic effect of PANI and MnO2 for each other and thus endow nano-PANI@MnO2 composite electrodes with their respective advantages. 4 Conclusions Nano-PANI@MnO2 nanometer tubular composites were successfully prepared by surface initiated polymerization of ANI using reactive template of MnO2 nanorods. The composites had excellent electrochemical performance containing the specific capacitance of the composite electrode higher than that of pristine PANI or MnO2, well high-power charge-discharge property (retention up to 79.5% at the current density of 20 mA/cm2) and excellent electric double-layer performance. The excellent electrochemical performances were mainly from the unique hierarchical nanostructure and some synergic function of the two compositions. Meanwhile, the facile and effective synthetic strategy made composite materials more promising for the application of electrochemical capacitors. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (51203071, 51363014 and 51362018), China Postdoctoral Science Foundation (2014M552509), the Opening Project of State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering (Sichuan University) (sklpme2014-4-25), the Program for Hongliu Distinguished Young Scholars in Lanzhou University of Technology (J201402), and the University Scientific Research Project of Gansu Province (2014B-025). coredata.dc:description: In this study, nano-polyanline and manganese oxide nanometer tubular composites (nano-PANI@MnO2) were prepared by a surface initiated polymerization method and used as electrochemical capacitor electrode materials; and the effect of aniline amount on the microstructure and electrochemical performance was investigated. The microstructures and surface morphologies of nano-PANI@MnO2 were characterized by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and fourier transformation infrared spectroscope. The electrochemical performance of these composite materials was performed with cyclic voltammetry, charge–discharge test and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, respectively. The results demonstrate that the feed ratio of aniline to MnO2 played a very important role in constructing the hierarchically nano-structure, which would, hence, determine the electrochemical performance of the materials. Using the template-assisted strategy and controlling the feed ratio of aniline to MnO2, the nanometer tubular structure of nano-PANI@MnO2 was obtained. A maximum specific capacitance of 386 F/g was achieved in aqueous 1 mol/L NaNO3 electrolyte with the potential range from 0 to 0.6 V (vs. SCE).
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of nano-PANI@MnO2 by surface initiated polymerization method using as a nano-tubular electrode material: The amount effect of aniline on the microstructure and electrochemical performance
